docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) BOOGIE MAN: THE LEE ATWATER STORY They called him the happy hatchet man and the Darth Vader of the Republican Party. In 1989, after masterminding the presidential victory of George H. W. Bush over Michael Dukakis -- including the infamous Willie Horton ad -- Lee Atwater (above right, mugging with Mr. Bush) was the political equivalent of a rock star, basking in the limelight of his new role as chairman of the Republican National Committee and mentoring political operatives like Karl Rove. Two years later Mr. Atwater died of a brain tumor at 41, but not before apologizing for some of his tactics. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis called this ''Frontline'' documentary about his rise and fall ''generous in spirit and nimble in technique.'' 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Six potentially deadly pains that should never be ignored; also, germs in restaurants. Eeew.

docs.lead_paragraph: You'd think that hundreds of people would have better things to do on a Friday night than go to a panel discussion at a museum. But the auditorium at the Paley Center for Media was packed elbow-to-elbow for the panel discussion "Writers Speak: A Potentially Regrettable Evening with the Writers of 'The Daily Show,'" part of the fifth annual New York Comedy Festival last week.
docs.abstract: Writers from "The Daily Show" discussed their daily routine, their career paths and whether the Obama administration will be good for comedy.
docs.snippet: Writers from "The Daily Show" discussed their daily routine, their career paths and whether the Obama administration will be good for comedy.
